journal-title-group.journal-subtitle: Processing of Biogenic Material for Energy and Chemistry

title-group.article-title: Drying of Chinese medicine residues (CMR) by hot air for potential utilization as renewable fuels: drying behaviors, effective moisture diffusivity, and pollutant emissions

institution-wrap.institution: School of Energy and Power Engineering
University of Shanghai for Science and Technology
Thermal and Environment Engineering Institute, School of Mechanical Engineering

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: High moisture in Chinese medicine residues (CMR) can decrease the energy efficiency of thermochemical conversion, which necessitates the pre-drying. Owing to the complex constituents and decoction, CMR may possess distinct drying characteristics. It is necessary to understand its drying behaviors, effective moisture diffusivity, and pollutant emissions for future design and optimization of an industrial-level dryer. In this study, the drying of four types of typical CMR in hot nitrogen was performed. Their condensate and exhaust gas were collected and characterized. The results indicated that their drying process was dominated by internal moisture transport mechanism with a long falling rate stage. Drying temperature influenced their drying process more greatly than N2 velocity did. Residual sum of squares, root mean square error, and coefficient of determination indicated that Weibull model demonstrated their drying process best. Their effective moisture diffusivity was in the range of 1.224 × 10–8 to 4.868 × 10–8 m2/s, while their drying activation energy ranged from 16.93 to 30.39 kJ/mol. The acidic condensate had high chemical oxygen demand and total nitrogen concentration and yet low total phosphorus concentration. The concentration of total volatile organic compounds, non-methane hydrocarbons, H2S, and NH3 in the exhaust gas met the national emission limitation, while the deodorization of exhaust gas was required to remove odor smell.

institution-wrap.institution: National Natural Science Foundation of China
Science and Technology Innovation Plan Of Shanghai Science and Technology Commission

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) has developed for thousands of years and popularized in more than 180 countries and regions [1]. With the prevalence of COVID-19, it made an important contribution in the fight against pneumonia, increasing its popularity and attentions. TCM contained Chinese medicinal material, Chinese herbal piece, Chinese herbal decoction, and Chinese patent medicine [2]. Among these, Chinese patent medicine resulted from the modernization of TCM, which was processed from Chinese medicinal materials as certain dosage forms in terms of prescribed prescriptions and preparation processes. High demand of Chinese patent medicine stimulated the generation of large amounts of dregs, namely Chinese medicine residues (CMR), which were discharged by the pharmaceutical plants. In China, the annual discharge of CMR was expected to 60 ~ 70 million tons [3]. High moisture content in CMR caused microbial spoilage and faster degradation. Its odor smelled unpleasant. If disposal of improperly, it might pose potential threats to local environment and human beings health.

TCM was primarily made up of plants (root, stem, leaf, and fruit), animals (viscera, skin, bone, organ, etc.), and some minerals [4]. Generally, plants occupied more than 87% [3]. Therefore, the main components of CMR were cellulose, hemicellulose, lignin, fat, protein, polysaccharide, and so on. It was regarded as renewable energy, which could be extracted through biochemical or thermochemical approaches [4]. With the advantages of efficient volume reduction and contamination destruction, the latter one such as gasification, pyrolysis, and incineration has gained more and more attentions [5–8]. Hydrogen-rich (67.31 vol.%) gas was produced via catalytic pyrolysis of herb residues in a moving bed reactor [9]. Slight torrefaction favored the increment of pyrolytic gas production significantly [10]. Combustion behaviors, mechanisms, flue gas emissions, and ash characteristics of CMR in oxy-fuel and air atmosphere were evaluated by Chen et al., and better combustion performance of CMR in air was reported [11]. The pilot-scale study on an herb residue disposal and utilization system based on gasification indicated that 20 wt.% of moisture in herb residues was qualified for stable gasification, meanwhile the pretreatment such as drying consumed 80.44% of chemical energy in the original herb residues [12]. Typically, CMR contained high moisture content of 60 ~ 75 wt.% [10, 12, 13]. High moisture content increased the energy requirements for its thermal treatment, which made the pre-drying become a crucial step in these thermochemical processes for bioenergy. Energy efficiency increased by 5 to 15% in a boiler using dried instead of wet biomass due to the increased combustion temperature and reduced flue gas volume [14, 15]. The optimal moisture content of 5 to 10% was proposed for biomass pyrolysis [16]. Al-Rumaihi et al. reduced the moisture content of camel dung to less than 15% via solar-drying for making it suitable for pyrolysis [17].

Drying was a complex process where heat and mass transfer took place simultaneously [18]. Its main bottleneck was to balance the energy consumption with the quality and final property of dried fuels. As the pre-treatment step integrated into thermochemical conversion processes, drying characteristics played a key role in the performance of subsequent reactors. Therefore, it was critical to identify the best operating conditions with economic benefits according to the energy consumption. At the same time, mechanical property and desired moisture content of dried fuels must be achieved. Mathematical modeling of drying kinetics was the initial step with an attempt to improve it and to optimize its efficiency. It was also the key to design and modify an industrial-scale dryer.

Numerous models were available for the prediction of drying kinetics. They generally could be divided into theoretical models, semi-empirical models, and empirical models. The theoretical models considered both external and internal resistance to moisture transfer. However, considering all the mechanisms took place in the feedstocks, the application of such kind of models was unfeasible [19]. Semi-empirical models were derived from Fick’s second law of diffusion or its simplification as Newton’s law of cooling [20]. They included Lewis, Page, Modified Page, Midilli, and Henderson and Pabis. Empirical models (Weibull, Wang and Singh, etc.) demonstrated the direct relationship of moisture ratio (MR) against drying time [21]. Due to the simplicity and flexibility, semi-empirical and empirical models were widely adopted to describe the drying characteristics of fruits, vegetables, biomass, herbs, and so on. Page model showed a good fitting with the air-drying process of blueberry pulp [22]. Kong et al. reported that Midilli model was an appropriate model for describing turnip slices’ drying using solar drying equipment and through natural sunlight [23]. The Midilli model could accurately predict the moisture ratio evolution of two types of brewer’s spent grains in the conventional electric convective dryer [24]. Weibull model was successful in predicting the moisture content of apricots, coroba slices, aloe vera gel, yam tubers, longan, and so on [25–28]. Drying technology also played a vital role in preparing Chinese medicine with the purpose of moisture removal from the fresh plants [29]. Thereby, dried Chinese medicine could be reserved in a long term with high quality [30]. Li et al. found that the optimal Page model enabled to depict the moisture loss process of sliced gastrodia elata under multiple hot-air drying variables [31]. Midilli model was found to be the best appropriate model for describing the convective solar drying kinetics of Marrubium vulgare leaves and Moroccan rosemary leaves [32, 33]. However, compared with the drying of single fresh Chinese medicine, CMR undoubtedly possessed distinct drying characteristics and thereafter kinetics. CMR generally contained several kinds of leaves, stems, roots, animals, etc. Each of them demonstrated various drying behaviors. What is more, CMR suffered from decocting. The decoction process of Chinese medicine was like blanching using hot water, ethanol, or their mixture to extract effective medicinal ingredients. Previous studies on agro-products and herbs indicated that blanching favored accelerating the drying rate (DR) by changing the physical properties of these samples such as permeability of the cell membranes [30, 34]. After the boiling of yam slices, its moisture movement decreased owing to the elevated heat and mass transfer resistance by starch gelatinization [35]. Longer drying duration and reduced drying rate was observed for hot air drying of boiling-pretreated yam slices. Therefore, effect of blanching on drying behaviors depended on feedstocks.

Among the diverse drying methods, due to the controllability and simplicity, hot air drying was widely preferred with the uniform and higher drying rate under the variable drying conditions [30, 35]. For the drying of agro-products and herbs, they mainly focused on the effect of drying methods and pretreatment on the quality of dried products. However, the energy consumption and final property of dried fuels was of the most importance for CMR drying, since drying was the first step of subsequent thermochemical conversion, which dominated the feasibility of this integrated process. Reversely, subsequent thermochemical step could provide steam, hot flue gas or fuels for the initial drying step to sustain this integrated process. To achieve this goal, it was necessary to investigate moisture diffusivity, drying characteristics, and mathematical modeling of drying kinetics targeting at the design and optimization of an industrial dryer.

Additionally, wastewater and exhaust gas were inevitably produced during drying. When Scots pine sawdust was dried in a laboratory-scale spouted bed dryer, condensate was generated with significant amounts of organic compounds including terpenes and volatile fatty acids [36]. Volatile compounds were considered the main bioactive constituents in Chinese herbal medicine [30, 37]. After decoction, part of medicinal compounds or solvent (i.e., ethanol) was remained in CMR samples. They might release together with the moisture and carrier gas during drying [38]. These by-products might be harmful to the environment and human body. Therefore, it was necessary to identify and determine the emissions of condensate and exhaust gas from CMR drying to realize its sustainable management.

To fill these knowledge gaps, drying behaviors and kinetics of four types of CMR were investigated using a home-made drying apparatus. In terms of experimental data, effective moisture diffusivity, activation energy, and kinetic model were identified. The condensate and exhaust gas collected during the drying of four CMR samples were characterized in this study. It can provide the guidance for the design of an industrial-level CMR dryer.

sec.title: Chinese medicine residues
sec.p: Four types of CMR samples, namely Suhuang (SH), Lanqin (LQ), Weisu (WS), and Huangqi (HQ), were collected from a pharmaceutical company in Jiangsu Province, P. R. China. Their constituents in terms of sources are summarized in Table S1. It could be judged that they were typical dregs from TCM including plants (i.e., roots, stems, leaves, fruits, seeds, bark) and animals (i.e., body and organ).

CMR samples were filled in several barrels and stored in a refrigerator at 4 °C to avoid decay. They were oven-dried at 105 ℃ to determine their initial moisture content. Proximate analysis was performed in a muffle furnace following the national standard GB/T 212–2008, while ultimate analysis was conducted in an elemental analyzer. Oxygen (O) content and fixed carbon content were calculated by difference. Additionally, an automated bomb calorimeter was employed for the determination of their higher heating values (HHV). Fundamental properties of four types of CMR samples are listed in Supporting Information Table S2.

sec.title: Drying procedure of CMR samples
sec.p:
Drying of CMR was performed with the experimental apparatus in Fig. 1. This apparatus was mainly divided into three parts such as N2 supply, drying, and product collection. The drying part was made of oil bath, electronic balance, stainless basket, and three-neck round-bottom flask. The three-neck round-bottom flask acted as a drying chamber. An oil bath with organosilicon conduction oil was used to heat the drying chamber. The oil temperature was regarded as drying temperature. The cylindrical stainless basket with the diameter of 3.50 × 10–2 m and the length of 9.00 × 10–2 m was made from the stainless wire mesh to serve as a sample carrier. During drying, the total mass of the basket and each CMR sample against time was automatically recorded by the electronic balance.Fig. 1
Experimental system for CMR drying. 1—Nitrogen cylinder, 2—flowmeter, 3—oil bath, 4—electronic balance, 5—stainless basket, 6—three-neck round-bottom flask, 7—condenser, 8—conical flask, 9—silica gel, 10—gas sampling bag

Ethanol was adopted to extract medicinal ingredients in HQ. Therefore, N2 instead of air was used as carrier gas in this study to avoid possible fire during drying. N2 velocity was controlled by a flowmeter. And N2 gas blown into the three-neck round-bottom flask through its left neck. It carried the released moisture and volatile substances together out of the right neck. They passed through the condenser and were collected as condensate in the conical flask. After drying by silica gel, the exhaust gas was collected in a gas sampling bag.

Prior to each drying experiment, every CMR sample was evenly filled into the cylindrical stainless basket. The oil bath and flowmeter were adjusted to the desired temperature and N2 velocity, respectively. Once achieved, they were maintained for 10 min to exhaust the air in the system and keep the drying chamber temperature steady. Then the stainless basket was placed in the center of the flask as soon as possible, as demonstrated in Fig. 1. During drying, the total mass was recorded by the electronic balance every 1 min. When the moisture ratio of each sample was less than 0.01, its drying process was over [39]. The sample mass during drying was calculated by the difference between the total mass and average mass of empty stainless basket (Table S3).

sec.title: Assignment of drying experiments
sec.p: About 14 g of SH, 16 g of LQ, 17 g of WS, and 14 g of HQ were separately filled in the stainless basket for each experiment. Their drying experiments were performed in two groups. In the first group, drying temperature was set at 130, 150, 170, and 190 °C with N2 velocity of 0.25 m/s. In the second group, drying temperature was fixed at 150 °C, meanwhile N2 velocity was kept at 0.25, 0.85, 2.50, and 5.00 m/s, respectively. Under these conditions, the drying chamber temperature and exhaust gas temperature were measured and summarized in Table S3. Additionally, detailed description of the experimental conditions and collection methods of condensate and exhaust gas are provided in Supporting Information Note S1 and Note S2.

Owing to the buoyancy effect, the weight of empty stainless basket was influenced by both drying temperature and N2 velocity under these conditions (Fig. S1). It was found that the weight of empty stainless basket varied minorly during drying. Therefore, average weight of empty stainless basket was adopted in this study (Table S3).

sec.title: Drying rate
Mathematical modeling of CMR drying
sec.p: Six normalized models including Lewis, Page, Midilli, Henderson and Pabis, Wang and Singh, and Weibull were proposed to describe the drying characteristics of each CMR sample (Table S4) [40, 41]. Experimental data were fitted in these models using non-linear regression.

sec.title: Effective moisture diffusivity
Activation energy
sec.p: The E can be calculated from the slope (-E/R) in Eq. (13), which is obtained by the linear fitting between lnDeff and 1/T.

sec.title: Characterization of condensate and exhaust gas
sec.p: Total phosphorus (TP), total nitrogen (TN), and chemical oxygen demand (COD) in the condensate from CMR drying were determined by molybdenum blue method, alkaline potassium persulfate digestion-ultraviolet (UV) spectrophotometry, and potassium dichromate method, respectively.

Total volatile organic compounds (TVOCs), non-methane hydrocarbons (NMHC), hydrogen sulfide, and ammonia in the exhaust gas from CMR drying were characterized by gas chromatograph-mass spectrometer (GCMS-QP2010Ultra), gas chromatograph (GC 9790), gas chromatograph (Clarus 580), and ultraviolet–visible spectrophotometer (T6 New Century), respectively.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Correlation analysis was performed to evaluate the effect of drying temperature and N2 velocity on the drying of each CMR sample. Pearson’s correlation coefficient (r) could be used to assess the linear relationship among these variables. Its value ranged from − 1 to 1. The closer the absolute value to 1, the stronger the linear correlation [48].

sec.title: Effect of drying temperature
sec.p:
Effect of drying temperature on MR and DR of four CMR samples is plotted in Fig. 2, Fig. 3, and Fig. S2, respectively. Their corresponding characteristic parameters including drying duration (t), DRa, maximum drying rate (DRm), initial drying rate (DRi), and the time corresponding to maximum drying rate (τm) are summarized in Table 1.Fig. 2
Effect of drying temperature on MR during the drying process of a SH, b LQ, c WS, and d HQFig. 3

Significant effect of drying temperature on the drying process of four CMR samples was observed in Fig. 2. The curves of MR against time became steeper as the drying temperature rose, suggesting the increased DR and shorter drying duration. In detail, when the drying temperature increased from 130 to 190 ℃, drying duration of SH reduced by 16.76, 45.95, and 52.43%, meanwhile its DRa increased greatly by 41.98, 120.99, and 148.15%, respectively. Identical trend was observed for LQ, WS, and HQ, respectively (Table 1). This phenomenon was attributed to the decrement of evaporation pressure, which decreased the moisture evaporation resistance from the feedstocks and accelerated the moisture evaporation [31]. Figure S2 and Fig. 3 visualize the evolution of DR with time or MR during the drying of four CMR samples. Increasing drying temperature gave rise to the increment of both DRi and DRm for all CMR samples. i.e., they moved from 1.46 × 10–2 to 3.56 × 10–2 g/(g·min) and from 1.68 × 10–2 to 4.19 × 10–2 g/(g·min) for SH, respectively. At the same time, the DRm appeared earlier with an increase by 11.11, 27.78, and 38.89% for LQ, respectively. Similar findings were reported for SH, WS, and HQ (Table 1). They were located at the MR of 0.7 to 0.9 for four CMR samples (Fig. 3). This phenomenon was associated with the accessibility of surface moisture and its subsequent diffusion to keep the constant DR at the beginning, which gave rise to higher moisture diffusion and consequently high DR [39, 49]. Overall, drying temperature obviously affected the drying process of CMR, which was confirmed by several authors when the drying of food products was conducted [41].

In addition, some differences in the drying process of four CMR samples were observed. At 130 ℃, the drying duration of SH was 72, 63, and 52 min shorter than that of LQ, WS, and HQ, since SH contained higher proportion of leaves and periostracum cicadae with relatively thin structure, which favored the migration of internal moisture to their surface. LQ and WS were rich in starch such as rhizomes. After the extraction of medicinal ingredients, starch gelatinization occurred. WS and LQ became sticky or pasty with lumpy structure. Figure S3 shows the lumpy structure of WS and LQ. The formation of a resistant film layer was negative to the drying process, which decreased the movement of water molecules [50, 51].

In Fig. 3 and Fig. S2, two stages, namely the acceleration phase and falling rate phase, composed the drying process of four CMR samples, while the constant drying rate phase was absent [35]. The extremely short acceleration phase with increasing DR initiated their drying process. It took far less time than the falling rate phase did. This acceleration phase was independent of feedstocks, and the small amount of superficial moisture that weakly bound to the solid matrix was mainly removed from the feedstocks [52]. Subsequently, the falling rate phase began. In this stage, the moisture was transported from the interior of the feedstocks to the surface by capillary force [53]. This phase was controlled by the diffusion of moisture from the interior of CMR to the surface, and the internal moisture diffusion dominated the drying process [54]. Drying temperature strongly influenced this process. High temperature led to larger thermal gradient between the air and feedstocks as well as higher internal moisture vapor pressure, which increased the DR [55, 56]. As shown in Table S3, the drying chamber temperature followed well with the drying temperature, which enhanced the surface moisture diffusion in their acceleration rate phase. A long falling rate phase appeared with slowly reduced DR in Fig. S2. In this stage, the rate of moisture evaporation reduced with the decreasing moisture content (Fig. 3).

Figure 4, Fig. 5, and Fig. S4 show the effect of N2 velocity on the moisture release from four CMR samples. Table 2 summarizes their characteristic parameters such as t, DRa, DRm, DRi, and τm. Although the effect of N2 velocity on their drying process was not as obvious as that of drying temperature, the decrement of drying duration was still observed.Fig. 4
Effect of N2 velocity on MR during the drying process of a SH, b LQ, c WS, and d HQFig. 5

At the same time, some interesting phenomena was observed in the drying process. As N2 velocity increased, different change patterns of MR and DR were observed among four CMR samples. N2 velocity had little effect on the initial drying stage of SH due to the almost overlapped MR and slight fluctuation of DR. However, the DR of LQ, WS, and HQ were maximized at 5.00 m/s. For example, the DRm of LQ increased from 2.92 × 10–2 to 3.30 × 10–2 g/(g·min) as N2 velocity rose from 0.25 to 5.00 m/s. An upward trend for DRa of SH, LQ, and WS was observed. The fluctuation of both DRa and DRi was observed for HQ. With the increase of N2 velocity from 0.25 to 5.00 m/s, drying duration of four CMR samples reduced by 31.17, 4.76, 15.58, and 8.48%, respectively. While the drying temperature increased from 130 to 190 ℃, their drying duration reduced by 52.43, 47.08, 59.68, and 57.81%, respectively. Overall, the effect of N2 velocity on the drying process was less profound than that of drying temperature. Correlation analysis of drying temperature in Fig. S5 verified this finding with the absolute r > 0.956, excluding the DRi of WS. The absolute r values under different N2 veolocity were obviously smaller than those under the drying temperature. In fact, N2 veolocity mainly affected the initial drying stage. Surface evaporation occurred at this stage, which was influenced by N2 velocity greatly. It was gradually replaced by an eavporation front which receded to the interior of feedstocks [57]. The same conclusion was drawn by Madaleno et al. and Chkir et al. when the drying process of granulated cork as well as the mixture of ground cactus cladodes and brewer’s grains was investigated [58, 59].

sec.title: Mathematical modeling of CMR drying
sec.p: Six mathematical models including Lewis, Page, Henderson and Pabis, Midilli, Wang and Singh, and Weibull were proposed to fit the experimental data from CMR drying. The constants such as a, b, n, and k in these models and their evaluation criteria including RSS, RSME and R2 are summarized in Supporting Information Table S5 and Table S6, respectively.

For the proposed models, the values of RSS, RMSE, and R2 ranged from 0.00454 to 3.02580, 0.00546 to 0.13950, and 0.779 to 0.999, respectively. It was found that the values of RSS, RMSE, and R2 for Weibull model were in the range of 0.00454 to 0.06400, 0.00546 to 0.01767, and 0.997 to 0.999, respectively, which were better than the other models. Poor fitting of Midilli model was observed with RSS > 1.53644, RMSE > 0.09322, and R2 < 0.901. Therefore, the drying process of CMR samples over time could be described best by Weibull model. Comparison of the experimental MR and predicted MR by Weibull model at different drying temperature and N2 velocity is shown in Fig. 6 and Fig. S6, respectively. High R2 of 0.997 ~ 0.999 was reported, indicating the excellent prediction ability of Weibull model.Fig. 6
Comparison of the experimental MR and predicted MR by Weibull model at different drying temperature: a SH, b LQ, c WS, and d HQ

In Table S5, the value of scale parameter k in Weibull model decreased with the drying temperature; the smaller the value of k, the higher the moisture removal rate. This finding agreed well with the results in Table 1 that the DR of each CMR sample increased with the increment of drying temperature. The shape parameter n indicated the moisture diffusion mechanism and was related to the mass transfer rate at the beginning of drying. When the value of n was greater than 1.0, it indicated that there was a hysteresis stage at the early stage of drying [60, 61]. All n values were above 1.0 in this study, suggesting that the DR in the early stage had a rising period, and there was no constant-speed drying period, which was confirmed by Fig. S2 and Fig. S4. The DR increased firstly and then decreased during the whole drying process.

sec.title: Effective moisture diffusivity and activation energy
sec.p:
CMR drying was an internal moisture diffusion-controlled process with a long falling rate stage. The Deff of four CMR samples could be calculated using Eq. (11) and is detailed in Table S8 and Table S9, respectively. Figure 7 shows the effect of drying temperature and N2 velocity on Deff. Within the investigated range, Deff of four CMR samples followed a descending order of SH > HQ > WS > LQ.Fig. 7
Effect of a drying temperature and b N2 velocity on Deff

As expected, the Deff of four CMR samples increased from 1.224 × 10–8 to 4.868 × 10–8 m2/s at the drying temperature of 130 ~ 190 ℃ and ranged from 1.433 × 10–8 to 3.029 × 10–8 m2/s at N2 velocity of 0.25 ~ 5.00 m/s, which was higher than the fresh Chinese herbal medicine. For example, the Deff of gastrodia elata was within the range of 7.510 × 10–9 and 1.504 × 10–8 m2/s at the air temperature of 45 to 60 ℃, while its value of nettle and mint leaves at 35 ~ 55 °C approximately ranged from 10–9 to 10–8 m2/s [31, 64]. The increment of drying temperature not only enhanced the internal moisture transport, but also accelerated the surface evaporation rate [65]. Therefore, higher Deff was observed. Additionally, CMR have undergone the decoction before drying, which was like hot-water blanching. Following decoction, the softened cell and reduced resistance increased the moisture diffusivity [66]. Furthermore, high temperature damaged their cell membrane and cell wall, making the internal moisture release more easily [67, 68]. Effect of decocting on the internal structure of CMR was much stronger than that of blanching, which might promote the drying process. Tunde-Akintunde and Nukulwar confirmed the enhancement of blanching on the drying process of pumpkin and gingers [69, 70]. In addition, SH mainly consisted of woody fiber-rich leaves [71]. Astragalus roots in HQ were mainly made from tough xylem. After decoction, their Deff increased more significantly.

In Fig. 7, Deff of SH was obviously higher than the other CMR samples. It increased with N2 velocity firstly and decreased subsequently. The opposite trend was observed for LQ. Several researchers have investigated the influence of air velocity on Deff. Ramachandran et al. found that the Deff increased with the air velocity when the distillers’ spent grain pellets were dried, while Srikiatden et al. reported that the air velocity sometimes decreased the Deff when the drying of cylindrical potato and carrot cores was performed [45, 72]. Higher N2 velocity could accelerate the diffusion of moisture from the CMR surface. At the same time, it might reduce their surface temperature as well.

sec.title: Characterization of condensate and exhaust gas from CMR drying
Condensate recovery rate
sec.p: Figure S7 shows the appearance of condensate collected during CMR drying. Comparing with deionized water, they were slightly light yellow. And no solid particles suspended in the condensate. However, they had obviously unpleasant smell.

The condensate recovery rate (Rc) and moisture content in the dried CMR samples are presented in Fig. 8. The Rc could be calculated following Eq. S1 in Supporting Information. For SH and WS, it decreased after an initial increase, while it fluctuated for LQ as the drying temperature increased. The value of Rc for HQ always augmented from 50.00 to 72.75% along with the decrement of moisture content in the dried CMR from 15.85 to 9.83%. At 190 °C, higher DR in the early stage led to more moisture release from these samples (Fig. S2), which could not be condensed sufficiently. Higher Rc yet lower moisture content was observed for SH comparing with the other CMR samples (Fig. 8), which was associated with its constituents. In the early stage of condensate collection, the moisture evaporated too fast to collect sufficiently. In the late drying stage, both slow moisture evaporation rate and relatively high N2 velocity might influence the condensate recovery as well. Therefore, in the industrial-level CMR drying, enhanced condensate recovery by cyclone separation was proposed.Fig. 8
Effect of drying temperature on Rc and final moisture content of a SH, b LQ, c WS, and d HQ

Final moisture content in the dried CMR samples showed a decreasing tendency with the increment of drying temperature. In Fig. 8, it reduced to 5.11, 7.51, 10.11, and 9.83% for SH, LQ, WS, and HQ, respectively when the drying temperature increased from 130 to 190 °C. Higher drying temperature promoted the evaporation of moisture from CMR samples, which has been discussed in Sect. 3.1.1 in detail.

sec.title: Characterization of condensate from CMR drying
sec.p:
pH, COD, TP, and TN in the condensate at different drying temperature are shown in Table 5. Acidic condensate with high COD and TN concentration and yet low TP concentration was collected from all samples. In general, it seemed that the higher the drying temperature, the larger the values of pH, COD, TN, and TP concentration. Drying temperature had more profound effect on COD and TN. i.e., their values of SH increased by 53.33 and 70.64%, respectively as the drying temperature rose. It had minor effect on pH and TP concentration. The TP concentration from four CMR samples was less than 1.0 mg/L.Table 5

High COD in the condensate was associated with the small molecular organic components such as alcohols and terpenes in the CMR samples, which evaporated together with the moisture [75, 76]. It was reported that the volatile components in the herbal essential oils accounted for about 90 ~ 95% [77]. In practice, medicinal ingredients in HQ were extracted by ethanol. Therefore, ethanol was remained, which contributed to extremely high COD concentration of 42,000 mg/L at 190 °C. Additionally, CMR samples were rich in organic acids [78, 79], such as Schisandrae Chinensis Fructus in SH and Isatidis Radix in LQ, which were responsible for the acidic condensate. In case of the condensate from the drying of Scots pine and poplar wood, the condensate pH ranged from 3.29 to 3.86 and from 2.56 to 3.42, respectively [80, 81], while that from the drying of olive pomace was within the range of 3.61 to 4.50 [82]. In addition, the presence of nitrogenous substances such as alkaloids and amino acids as well as ester in CMR was inevitably collected in the condensate. So did the phosphorus-containing substances.

According to the discharge standard of water pollutants for pharmaceutical industry—Chinese traditional medicine category (GB 21,906–2008), pH, COD, and TN in the condensate exceeded the emission limitation, while TP concentration was far less than its limitation (Table 5). Additionally, it was reported that the optimum mass concentration ratio of COD:N:P for the aerobic and anaerobic treatment of high organic matter wastewater were 100:5.0:1.0 and 250:5.0:1.0, respectively [83, 84]. The condensate from CMR drying exhibited poor mass concentration ratio of COD:N:P. i.e., the condensate collected during the drying of SH at 190 °C showed high TN concentration and yet low TP concentration with COD:N:P of 250:11.55:0.08. Therefore, the condensate from CMR drying should be treated by aerobic and anaerobic co-digestion with other wastewater, advanced oxidation, and so forth to meet the discharge standard [38, 85].

sec.title: Characterization of exhaust gas from CMR drying
sec.p:
The medicinal ingredients of Chinese herbal medicine included volatile organic compounds (VOCs), whose composition affected the medicinal property, and was widely used in pharmaceuticals production [86, 87]. NMHC, H2S, and NH3 were air pollutants identified by the pharmaceutical industry, and it was necessary to determine their concentrations in the exhaust gas from CMR drying. VOCs including acetone, n-hexane, isopropanol, ethyl acetate, benzene, hexamethyldisiloxane, n-heptane, 3-pentanone, methylbenzene, cyclopentanone, ethyl lactate, butyl acetate, ethylbenzene, p/m-xylene, propylene glycol monomethyl ether, styrene, o-xylene, 2-heptanone, anisole, benzaldehyde, and 1-decene were detected in the exhaust gas. Detected VOCs, NMHC, H2S, and NH3 in the exhaust gas from CMR drying are summarized in Table 6. Among these VOCs, toluene and butyl acetate presented in the exhaust gas from all CMR samples, while p/m-xylene and o-xylene were existed in the exhaust gas from LQ, WS, and HQ samples. The concentration of TVOCs from four CMR samples was 0.651, 0.845, 0.567, and 0.690 mg/m3, respectively.Table 6

H2S was not detected in the exhaust gas. NMHC in the exhaust gas was harmful to human body and environment due to the potential photochemical pollution [88]. NH3 was an air pollutant with strong pungent odor. NMHC concentration in the exhaust gas from SH, LQ, WS, and HQ was 0.4490, 0.4397, 0.5598, and 0.4818 mg/m3, while NH3 concentration was 0.012, 0.012, 0.015, and 0.012 mg/m3, respectively. They met the limitation in the emission standard of air pollutants for pharmaceutical industry (GB 37,823–2019). However, unpleasant odor in the exhaust gas necessitated deodorization during the CMR drying, such as adsorption and biological treatment.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this study, drying characteristics and kinetics of four CMR samples were explored comprehensively. Meanwhile, the condensate and exhaust gas from these samples were characterized. Drying process of four CMR samples was dominated by the internal moisture transport mechanism with a long falling rate stage. Effect of temperature on their drying process was more obvious than that of N2 velocity in this study. Larger DR and shorter drying duration were observed at higher drying temperature. Weibull model described the moisture loss process of four CMR samples best. Within the investigated range, Deff followed a descend order of SH > HQ > WS > LQ. Their values increased from 1.224 × 10–8 to 4.868 × 10–8 m2/s with drying temperature and ranged from 1.433 × 10–8 to 3.029 × 10–8 m2/s at different N2 velocity. Drying activation energy was within the range of 16.93 to 30.39 kJ/mol, suggesting easy drying of CMR samples could be achieved. Acidic condensate was collected with high COD and TN concentration while low TP concentration. The concentrations of TVOCs, NMHC, H2S, and NH3 in the exhaust gas met the emission limitation. However, deodorization was required for CMR drying due to its unpleasant odor.

sec.title: Author contribution
sec.p: Zhenyang Feng and Xiaoyuan Zheng designed research, performed research, analyzed data, and wrote the paper. The remaining authors discussed the results and revised the manuscript.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The authors appreciate the financial supports from National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant number 51706144), Natural Science Foundation of Shanghai (Grant number 17ZR1419500), and Shanghai Municipal Science and Technology Committee of Shanghai Outstanding Academic Leaders Plan (Grant number 21XD1402400).

sec.title: Availability of data and materials
sec.p: All data generated or analyzed during this study are included in this submission and its supplementary materials file.

sec.title: Ethical approval
sec.p: Not applicable.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
